results.title: [Brookes Family Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
This film shows a family visit to the beach and backyard play in Point Lonsdale c1950s -1960s. We see the children (James, Andrew and Margaret] with their mother and father playing on the seashore, building sandcastles together and drawing pictures in the sand. Joined by their pet dog, the children fill their buckets with sand and play with seaweed washed up onto the beach. There are good closeups of the children, reflecting examples of children’s fashion and hairstyles of the era.

We see the children venture out to the edge of the water and then play along the top of the seawall. There is great delight while eating ice cream from cones, and tears shed when an adult takes an uninvited taste.

The second, third and fourth sections of the film show the children on a summer’s day in a backyard. Tricycles, a blow-up wading pool with the backyard hose leading into it, swings and a sand pit create a great snapshot of children’s recreation, toys, and equipment particular to the era. We also see a young boy kicking what appears to be an American shaped football and two boys playing with toy cars and a toy police car.

The fifth section of the film shows a young baby being held by her mother. We then see the baby lying in her pram and being closely inspected and entertained by her older sibling.

We then go back to the beach with three very young children playing on the water’s edge with their mother beside them. Adults sit on the sand socialising, and there are scenes on the veranda of a holiday house. We see great examples of beach fashion, women’s hats, and children’s swimsuits.

This film shows examples of Victoria in the summertime, beach, women’s fashion and children’s fashion, children’s swim wear, vintage toys and a perambulator, children’s leisure and recreation activities that reflect the time.

Originally made using 16mm film.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 5: Part 2]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is part two of two and is titled ‘Innes National Park’, and contains scenes from the Park, located in South Australia, including the rolling wavy sea viewed from rocky cliff tops of the park coastline, the dunes, wildflowers and beach tracks.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:04:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Innes National Park’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:55:00 campsite including an open fire with ‘billycan’, and a tarpaulin being set up as cover.
00:04:07:00 sign for ‘Innes National Park’
00:04:27:00 sign for ‘Shell Beach’
00:06:15:00 shifting sands in a dune.
00:08:04:00 sign for ‘The Gap’
00:08:51:00 ‘Inneston’ sign
00:10:36:00 ‘Stenhouse Bay’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 5: Part 1]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 4: Part 2]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film, titled ‘Orchid Isle’, is the second of two parts capturing the filmmaker’s travels in Fiji. Wallace films townships, harbours and local buildings in the thatched Fijian style. He also captures some tourist attractions such as the capital city of Fiji - Suva, Fijian performers and lush garden walks.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 4: Part 1]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film, titled ‘Fascinating Fiji’, contains scenes of Fiji landscapes, towns and resorts. The filmmaker takes footage from a vehicle so that the scenes change with his travels. Much of the reel is taken up with scenic vistas of roadside crops, lush greenery, trees and flowers, hills in the distance and the sea.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke.

In this film, the filmmaker shows life on and around the beach at Anglesea in Victoria - walking, hang gliding, surfing, motoring in the dunes and on the sand, taking in the views from the cliffs. Wallace focuses on examples of coastal wildflowers as well as animal life where he finds it.

Originally made using Super 8mm film.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke.

This film, titled ‘Arnhem Land’, contains scenes from a trip to Arnhem Land and Katherine in the Northern Territory in the 1970s.

Travel is by jeep on dusty roads, boats and walking. Wallace captures the varied landscapes of rivers, rocky outcrops, hills, trees, flowers and the scrub as well as termite mounds. He also films buffalo, lizards and waterbirds. A highlight is the Aboriginal rock art drawings throughout the film.

Originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 titles ‘WHC Presents’ and ‘Arnhem Land Safari’
00:01:08:00 sign for the township of Katherine in the Northern Territory.
00:02:05:00 truck travels along a dirt road with scrub burning-off on either side.
00:02:29:00 truck travelling crossing a river.
00:02:48:00 pictorial map of the Jim Jim Falls area.
00:03:28:00 canvas tents at a campsite.
00:06:55:00 four wheel drive and trailer.
00:07:52:00 water buffalo.
00:08:00:00 very large bird in equally large nest at the top of a tree.
00:14:30:00 sign ‘Northern Territory Administration Aboriginal Reserve’.
00:13:45:00 examples of Aboriginal rock art drawings which appear until the end of the reel.
00:24:50:00 swimsuits of the era while swimming in a river.
00:27:00:00 digging a tourist bus out of a sandy track.
00:28:58:00 skeletal remains in the mouth of a cave.

results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. results.title: Jaara Nyilamum
results.creator_credit: Lou Bennett AM and Romaine Moreton
results.credit_line:
Romaine Moreton (Goenpul Yagerabul Minjungbal Bundjalung) and Lou Bennett AM (Dja Dja Warrung, Yorta Yorta)
Single-channel video, 7:39 mins.
Filmed and edited by Romaine Moreton
Co-directed by Romaine Moreton and Lou Bennett AM
ACMI Collection

Jaara Nyilamum (song composition) Performed by Dr Lou Bennett AM and the Australian String Quartet
Composed by Dr Lou Bennett AM
Arranged by Iain Grandage
Produced by Stephen Snelleman
results.brief_description:
2021, Romaine Moreton (Goenpul Yagerabul Minjungbal Bundjalung), Lou Bennett AM (Dja Dja Warrung, Yorta Yorta)
Filmed & Edited by Romaine Moreton, Co-Directed by Romaine Moreton & Lou Bennett AM
H264 projection,16:9, colour, 7:39 mins
Jaara Nyilamum (song composition) Performed by Dr Lou Bennett AM and the Australian String Quartet, Composed by Dr Lou Bennett AM, Arranged by Iain Grandage, Produced by Stephen Snelleman

Dr Lou Bennett is a Performer, Songwriter, Musical and Artistic Director, Composer, Actor, Soundscape Designer and Academic. Lou’s research project ‘Sovereign Language Rematriation Through Song Pedagogy’ focusses on the importance and relevance of Indigenous language retrieval, reclamation, and regeneration through the medium of the Arts to enhance community health and wellbeing. Dr Romaine Moreton is an artist, writer, performer, filmmaker, and her proposes an Indigenous philosophy of story-telling and embodied knowledge, with her work constantly drawing our attention back to the importance of the breath in Indigenous cultural practices.

The making of Jaara Nyilamum (2021) evoked a stillness that restored us to full sensual immersion within country, and from this place of rooted calmness, country reaffirmed our Law is real. Jaara Nyilamum became most profound when we realised this was more than a film about ceremony, but was in fact, ceremony itself. Our challenge was to create a production model that aligned with our beliefs and centralised our Law, pushed back against monochronic time and engaged with the deep cycles of place, where we embraced Belonging as a process of constant renewal and Rematration.

results.title: [Brookes Family Home Movies: Reel 6]
results.brief_description:
This film captures a slice of recreational family life in Australia. We see scenes of people enjoying the water and sunshine at Shelly beach on the Mornington Peninsula, Victoria. There are also scenes from a children’s backyard party.

The film starts at the beach where the Brookes family enjoy a day out in Port Phillip Bay, watching the Lazy E (now called the National E) state championship race. Also seen are some old style dingies, catamarans, Sabot and Mirror boats sailing, while the learn to sail on a sailboard. Moored speed boats are seen at Portsea, while people are swimming and children enjoying themselves on the shore.

The second section of this film shows a family and friends event, which could be a children’s birthday party, being celebrated in a suburban back yard. There is very funny footage of children playing various party games including the Chocolate Game. This game involves participants rolling a dice, racing to dress up in a costume and then eating chocolate with a knife and fork. There is also a Dress Up Relay race. We see the children dash back and forth with costumes packed into a TEAL branded airline - style bag. The TEAL acronym may stand for Tasman Empire Airways Limited, which was the forerunner of Air New Zealand, established in 1940. The children unpack their costumes, dress up and then dash back to the next person in line, all the while keeping an eye on how fast their competition is going.

There is an amusing sequence of children playing the Lifesaver Toothpick game. The first player in the line is given a lifesaver lolly to hold in their mouth with a toothpick, they then transfer the lifesaver to the next person holding a toothpick in their mouth without using their hands.

There is some trampoline action and a game of Pin the Tail on the Donkey. The Donkey in this instance appears to be called “Flowery”. There is also a balloon catching game played around an above ground backyard swimming pool, and Food on a String being played using chocolate, coconut covered snowballs strung from a monkey bar. The children try to eat them without using their hands.

The film also shows children playing in the street with historical cars parked alongside them. One of these cars appears to be a black Volkswagen Beetle and one appears to be a Pontiac.

There are also scenes of family members fly-fishing in a dam. This dam could possibly be Rocky Valley Dam - a prime fly-fishing body of water just out of Falls Creek Victoria on the Omeo road. It is also sometimes referred to as Rocky Valley Lake and is the water storage dam for the Kiewa Valley, Victoria. Parked at this location are the family vehicles which look like a Citroen Station Wagon from the DS series and a Morris Minor.

This film shows excellent examples of recreational activities, sailing dinghys and yachts, children’s party games, children’s fashion, and vehicles typical to the era.

This film was made on 16mm film.

00:02:14:00 Mirror or Sabot boat sailing with speed boat anchored in foreground

00:04:44:00 Mirror or Sabot boat hitched to the back of a Citroen, registration number JEW 818
